items.title: Error 500 when trying to register my YubiKey on the demo
items.body:
I'm currently evaluating solutions to improve the security of my current Django project.
The possibility of providing different 2FA mechanisms out of the box is appealing.
However, upon pressing my YubiKey to input an OTP, the demo site triggers a server error.

## Expected Behavior
Well, I'm expecting... some kind of registration confirmation page, I guess? :)

## Current Behavior
Upon pressing my YubiKey's input button, the input field gets populated with a long string, as expected.
Then the form gets auto-submitted, which in turns triggers a server error (500).

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
1. Log into the demo website with a registered account
2. Click the _Enable Two-Factor Authentication_ button
3. Click the _Next_ button
4. Select the _YubiKey_ radio button, then click the _Next_ button
5. Click into the _YubiKey_ input field, then plug a YubiKey into a USB port and put your finger on its activation zone.
6. The input field gets populated with a long string
7. The form gets auto-submitted
8. The browser shows a _Server Error (500)_ message

## Your Environment
* Browser and version: Latest versions of Chrome and Firefox on macOS Catalina 10.15.5

items.title: Incomplete test for CVE-2020-15105 password in session
items.body:
While reviewing https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth/commit/fb9ee1962e07bb07546ee4155e0aee5892638b9d, which seems to have been written in response to https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-vhr6-pvjm-9qwf:

> django-two-factor-auth versions 1.11 and before store the user's password in clear text in the user session (**base64-encoded**).

(emphasis added) I noticed that this test does not check for a base64-encoded password as described by the security advisory. The test only verifies that a plain-text version of the password is not stored in the session:

https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth/blob/fb9ee1962e07bb07546ee4155e0aee5892638b9d/tests/test_views_login.py#L410-L412

While being a reasonable check, this test seems like it would not have caught the issue that was recently fixed in v1.12.

Perhaps another test should be added or a second assertion should be added to the test? Something like:
```py
from base64 import b64encode
encoded_secret = b64encode('secret'.encode('utf8')).decode('ascii').strip()
self.assertNotIn(encoded_secret, session_contents)
```

items.title: README.rst has text that causes encoding issues
items.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->
When pulling the latest `master` of this repo as a python package with pip, I get an encoding error:
```
Obtaining two_factor from git+https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth#egg=two_factor (from -r requirements.txt (line 23))
  Cloning https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth to /two-factor
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/src/two-factor/setup.py", line 7, in <module>
        long_description=open('README.rst').read(),
      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 1097: ordinal not in range(128)
```

## Expected Behavior
The weirdly encoded character `⚠️` should be removed from the `README.rst`

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->
In the latest commit 3f1b8f5, the odd character was added.  Please remove if possible or use an ascii friendly character.

items.body:

Different problems when installing the library using Python 2.7 and Django 1.11

### Steps to Reproduce

1. I install the library according to the [steps](https://django-two-factor-auth.readthedocs.io/en/stable/installation.html).
2. The first error is:`ImportError: No module named phonenumbers`. I install the phone library and it is solved :)
3. I recharge the project and another error: `ImportError: No module named parse` 
```File "/Users/user/Workspace/myproject/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/apps/registry.py", line 116, in populate
    app_config.ready()
  File "/Users/user/Workspace/myproject/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/contrib/admin/apps.py", line 23, in ready
    self.module.autodiscover()
  File "/Users/user/Workspace/myproject/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/contrib/admin/__init__.py", line 26, in autodiscover
    autodiscover_modules('admin', register_to=site)
  File "/Users/user/Workspace/myproject/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/utils/module_loading.py", line 50, in autodiscover_modules
```

It seems that the way of importing is different. I change `from urllib.parse import quote, urlencode` -> `from urllib import quote, urlencode` and it's ok.

items.title: ThreadLocals middleware is using deprecated MiddlewareMixin
items.body:
## Expected Behavior
ThreadLocals should not inherit from MiddlewareMixin

## Possible Solution
Rewrite ThreadLocals to inherit from object and implement `init` and `call` methods as described here:
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.0/topics/http/middleware/#writing-your-own-middleware


## Context
Upgrading to Django 2.2.X (and beyond) will give Deprecation warnings about this. This is not yet on the list to be removed, but better to be prepared.

## Your Environment

* Python version: 3.6.10
* Django version: 1.11 and 2.2.7
* django-otp version: 0.7.5
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.10.0

Looking at [django-phonenumber-field release notes](https://github.com/stefanfoulis/django-phonenumber-field/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst), there doesn't seem to be any breaking changes up till [3.0.0](https://github.com/stefanfoulis/django-phonenumber-field/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst#300-2019-05-28)

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->
I think it's possible to simply limit it to `2.99` seeing that no breaking changes have been introduced.

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->
The problem shows where I had a local dependency for `django-phonenumber-field`, and when I installed `django-two-factor-auth`, the `setup.py` replaced my current `django-phonenumber-field` dependency to an older version, which caused the app to break.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* Browser and version:
* Python version: 3.6
* Django version: 2.2.4
* django-otp version: 0.6.0
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.9.1

```diff
class QRGeneratorView(View):

    def get(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
       ...

        otpauth_url = get_otpauth_url(accountname=username,
```

items.title: Drop support for Django 1.11?

Currently the package is compatible with every supported version of Django currently available. items.title: Compatibility issues with django 2.2
items.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Problem
I have been using two_factor with Django 2.1 for a while without any problems (thank you for all your work!). However, I recently upgraded to Django 2.2 and am having some compatibility issues. Whilst I am still able to create ```PhoneDevice``` objects, I can now no longer delete them (both within the shell environment and the relevant views e.g. ```PhoneDeleteView``` and ```DisableView```). In both cases, I get the same error. For example, if I enter the following in the shell ``` PhoneDevice.objects.first().delete() ``` I get the following error:

``` console
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/iwilliams/.virtualenvs/twofactor/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/base.py", line 918, in delete
    collector.collect([self], keep_parents=keep_parents)
  File "/home/iwilliams/.virtualenvs/twofactor/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/deletion.py", line 192, in collect
    reverse_dependency=reverse_dependency)
  File "/home/iwilliams/.virtualenvs/twofactor/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/db/models/deletion.py", line 94, in add
    if obj not in instances:
TypeError: unhashable type: 'PhoneDevice'
```

## Possible Solution
Part of the problem seems to lie with the following method:

``` Python
class PhoneDevice(Object):
   ...
    def __eq__(self, other):
        if not isinstance(other, PhoneDevice):
            return False
        return self.number == other.number \
            and self.method == other.method \
            and self.key == other.key
```
When the above function is commented out, I am able to remove PhoneDevice objects. Perhaps on a related note, I should note that I can add ```TOTPDevice``` and ```YubikeyDevice``` instances in Django 2.2 without a problem, both of which don't override the base ```__eq__``` method. 

Do you have any further insight into what is causing this problem/ how it can be properly resolved?

Thanks in advance!

## Environment Info
* Python version: 3.6.7
* Django version: 2.2
* django-otp version: 0.6.0
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.8.0

items.title: Post requests with missing management form data to LoginView cause 500 errors
items.body:
If a client submits a username and password, but for some reason *doesn't* also send "login_view-current_step" (let's say it's a bot sweeping the Internet for login forms and then trying common username/password combinations), an exception is raised.

## Expected Behavior

Either a client error (HTTP 400?) or a form error as would happen with an invalid username/password/token.

## Current Behavior

A `ValidationError` is raised but not caught. The causes a 500 error and an alert for developers/admins.

## Possible Solution

Replace `ValidationError` with `SuspiciousOperation`. This exception gets logged with `django.security.*` rather than `django.request`, so it can be processed differently if admins prefer: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/topics/logging/#django-security

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)

1. Go to your login page
2. Use the HTML inspector to remove the "login_view-current_step"  hidden input
3. Submit the form and see you have received a 500 error response

## Context

The current error produces an error that looks like a server error rather than a client error. I think this bug is also present in django-formtools, but both LoginView and IdempotentSessionWizardView override the post method and manually raise a `ValidationError`.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* Browser and version: Firefox 57
* Python version: Python 2.7.14
* Django version: Django 1.11.9
* django-otp version: 0.4.2
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.7.0
* Link to your project: https://github.com/Inboxen/Inboxen

items.title: Passwords are stored in plain-text in the user's session
items.body:
When using the login wizard the user's password is stored in plain text in the session store. The information is stored by formtools' wizard class. This is a security risk, depending on the deployment this can easily lead to a leak. Imagine a shared database ...

The information is not required to complete the token step, it would suffice to store the authentication state once the user's username and password are verified and then call `login()` in the `done()` method.

items.title: Auth backends doesn't get "request" param when login via 2fa login view
items.body:
Auth backends doesn't get "request" param when using this package.

## Expected Behavior
Django 1.11 introduced "request" arg in `authenticate` method of auth backends (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/customizing/#writing-an-authentication-backend)
Expected to get request instance upon authentication.

## Current Behavior
Currently i get `None` instead of request there. Django two factor doesn't pass request to auth form at auth step so at the end backend authenticate method getting None instead of request instance.

## Possible Solution
Pass request via form kwargs like django doing in its `get_form_kwargs` inside `django.contrib.auth.views.LoginView`

Something like this should work i think:
`two_factor.views.core.LoginView`

```python
    def get_form_kwargs(self, step=None):
        """
        AuthenticationTokenForm requires the user kwarg.
        """
        if step == 'auth':
            return {
                'request': self.request
            }

        if step in ('token', 'backup'):
            return {
                'user': self.get_user(),
                'initial_device': self.get_device(step),
            }
        return {}
```
Pass request only at auth step. This will push request further and won't break other forms.

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
1. setup 2fa
2. add logging into auth backends authenticate method
3. see that request always None

## Context
I have custom auth backend that rely on request information (sessions, etc.). Without this change i can't use it.

## Your Environment

* Browser and version: any
* Python version: 2.7
* Django version: 1.11.2
* django-otp version: 0.3.14
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.6.2

items.title: Authentication backend's authenticate() method is called 3 times during a successful authentication
items.body:
## Current Behavior
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->
I am using this package with a custom authentication backend and logging the calls to the authenticate() method. It seems there are 3 calls to authenticate() during a successful authentication (instead of 1).

## Possible Cause
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

The formtools wizard post() method called from IdempotentSessionWizardView's [post()](https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth/blob/master/two_factor/views/utils.py#L138) contains 3 direct or indirect calls to form.is_valid():

1. `if form.is_valid():` [here](https://github.com/django/django-formtools/blob/master/formtools/wizard/views.py#L301)

2. `self.steps.last` [here](https://github.com/django/django-formtools/blob/master/formtools/wizard/views.py#L307)

3. `return self.render_done(form, **kwargs)` [here](https://github.com/django/django-formtools/blob/master/formtools/wizard/views.py#L309)

Each of these 3 calls is triggering a form.is_valid() call, and as a consequence, an authentication backend authenticate() call.

I am a bit unsure if this issue is better addressed in this project, in formtools or in contrib.auth's AuthenticationForm. I think the root cause is the use of contrib.auth's AuthenticationForm within the formtools wizard.

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. Create a custom authentication backend based on the default ModelBackend https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/auth/backends.py#L7-L103
2. Log calls to authenticate()
3. Login successfully (even with a non-2FA user) and check the log for 3 calls to authenticate()

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->
In the context of a remote user authentication backend, 3 external API calls to a remote server can add significantly to the time needed for logging in - it degrades performance and scalability.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* Python version: 3.4
* Django version: 1.11.1
* django-two-factor-auth version: 1.6.2

items.title: feature suggestion:  allow "once-only" display of backup tokens once setup is complete
items.body:
this is a security enhancement proposal I guess?

we were thinking of adding an extra layer of security to our site by, for example, requiring a token if the user wishes to change their password, disable tfa, or perform other sensitive account operations.  this means that, even if a user has their session hijacked somehow, or perhaps leaves their computer unguarded, an attacker cannot do too much damage.

but then we realised that the attacker can just go to the "view my backup tokens" page (from `two_factor.views.BackupTokensView`) and use one of the backup tokens.

we could disable that view, but that same information is still available via the "success_url" of `two_factor.views.SetupView` -- we do have to display the backup tokens to the user at least once, and if we do so from a page with a normal GET request, then it has a URL, and it can be viewed again.

so the feature request is:  some way of being able to display backup tokens "once-only", such that they can't ever be seen again.  options:

- use django messages framework at the end of a successful trip through `SetupView`
- render a one-off template after processing the final `SetupView` POST instead of redirecting to a sucess_url

I think we might have a go at the first of those two options.   Do let me know if I'm making some obvious mistake or I have misunderstood something here?

items.title: Fake 2fa for test ?
items.body:
Hi,

I have a question. Maybe I've missed it in the docs but is there a build in way to disable the ```@otp_required``` for when running tests ? 

Example I have this view:
```python
@otp_required
def generate(request):
    pass
```
With a TestCase:

```python
def test_generate(self):
      response = self.client.get('/generate', follow=False)
      self.assertEqual(response.status_code, 200)

      response2 = self.client.post('/generate', follow=False)
      self.assertEqual(response2.status_code, 200)
```
Because the test is not logged in with 2fa, it will get redirected and the actual code of the view, in this case `pass`, will not get tested.

If there is no build in way, could you point me in the right direction on how to write a test that will bypass the decorator and test the code of the view. 

Thx in advance.

items.title: Autofocus token input during authentication
items.body:
Opening as an issue first for any background discussion before a PR.

Token input usually comes directly after user:pass input.  The user already has their hands on the keyboard and the token is the only field for input in the wizard flow.  It should auto focus, so no additional tab or mouse clicks are necessary to complete authentication.

While this could be a template decision, since the authentication workflow is wrapped in a wizard, I think changing the AuthenticationTokenForm makes the most sense.

```
grind@hollywood:~/git/django-two-factor-auth/two_factor$ git diff
diff --git a/two_factor/forms.py b/two_factor/forms.py
index 7e61ce9..57dbc90 100644
--- a/two_factor/forms.py
+++ b/two_factor/forms.py
@@ -142,6 +142,8 @@ class AuthenticationTokenForm(OTPAuthenticationFormMixin, Form):
     otp_token = forms.IntegerField(label=_("Token"), min_value=1,
                                    max_value=int('9' * totp_digits()))
 
+    otp_token.widget.attrs.update({'autofocus': 'autofocus'})
+
     # Our authentication form has an additional submit button to go to the
     # backup token form. When the `required` attribute is set on an input
     # field, that button cannot be used on browsers that implement html5
```

items.title: Cannot reach backup codes screen without putting in a dummy token
items.body:
Django will generate a required `IntegerField` with a `required` attribute (and min/max validators):

``` html
<input id="id_token-otp_token" max="999999" min="1" name="token-otp_token" required="" type="number">
```

This means in some recent browsers (certainly Firefox, here) you can't submit the token form using the "Use backup token" button, because you get a validation error on the token input field. This needs to be an optional field, or you have to put a valid but dummy token in (eg 1), which isn't particularly guessable for most people. That will then require some more subtle validation of the `Form` on the backend (and possibly some dynamic rather than declarative validation on the front end).

items.title: Password protected pages
items.body:
Hello,

I have recently integrated this package into our current Django auth workflow without any issues. I believe that we could increase security by adding password protected pages for:
- Show Backup Tokens (`/two_factor/backup/tokens/`)
- Disable Two-factor Authentication (`/two_factor/disable/`)

The idea is that someone could access a logged in user computer maliciously and grab its token or even disable the two step auth on their behalf. A good way of preventing this security weakness would be to ask the user to re-enter their login password to see the backup token and disable two-factor auth.

Those pages would present a password form and on POST success display the backup tokens or disable the two-factor auth.

I wonder if you guys think it's worth implementing, or if you could point me to the best approach of doing so in a fork.

items.title: Django 1.7 still listed as supported, while it isn't
items.body: In the docs and the readme Django 1.7 is still listed as being supported, while it isn't. The docs and readme should be updated to reflect this.

items.title: Django formtools is a hard dependency
items.body: Currently, the docs state that on Django 1.8 and higher, `django-formtools` should be installed. As Django 1.8 is the minimal version supported by django-tfa, it has been made hard dependency. All references to manual installation should be updated as well.

items.title: Redirect to profile after deleting a phone
items.body:
https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth/blob/master/two_factor/views/core.py#L476

When you delete a phone now, it will take you to `settings.LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL`, which for most people is the homepage.

items.title: What needs to happen for this to be recommended for production use?
items.body:
Since this package seems to be the most complete Django project doing 2FA, and I don't think every Django project should write its own 2FA support, I'd like to use this in Zulip (https://github.com/zulip/zulip/).

It's hard to miss the warnings on GitHub and pypi that this package is unmaintained and not recommended for production use.  But I've noticed that code has been merged over the last few months; is the package maintained again now?  

If not, what would it take to make this package ready for production use?  Are there known significant bugs that need to be resolved, should we be trying to recruit someone to help out with maintaning this at DjangoCon next week, or something else?

items.title: Missing migration
items.body:
This commit changed a model field:
https://github.com/Bouke/django-two-factor-auth/commit/0ba9fea143d04152f5837384a93a02257ea3c682#diff-2afce380c543f1ec32ec166198de5498L13

As a consequence, it needs a migration.

Before this commit, the max length for phone numbers was 16. After this commit, it's 128 (the default of django-phonenumber-field). As a consequence, numbers with a length between 17 and 128 inclusive pass Django's validation but are rejected by the database.

I noticed this issue while making consistency checks on a database schema. I haven't encountered it in practice because people don't tend to enter numbers with more than 16 digits.

Even if you set the length limit back to 16 digits, you should still make a migration for Django to record the change.

items.title: Spurious migrations on Python 3
items.body:
In a Python 3 project that uses django-two-factor-auth, when running `django-admin makemigrations`, Django generates migrations which, and as far as I can tell, only change `help_text` attributes from byte strings to unicode strings.

This problem happens because django-two-factor-auth and django-otp were initially written for Python 2. The `help_text` attributes of their models are bytes objects (which are the same as str on Python 2). For compatibility with Python 3, Django serializes them explicitly as bytestrings with a `b` prefix in migrations, even though you likely intended them to be native strings (bytes on Python 2, unicode on Python 3).

To fix this problem, you should convert `help_text` attributes unicode, typically by adding `from __future__ import unicode_literals` in `models.py`. (If the file contains a string literal that must be a bytestring for crypto purposes, mark it with a `b` prefix.) See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/topics/python3/ and feel free to reach out to me if you have questions.

FYI this is exactly the same issue as https://bitbucket.org/psagers/django-otp/issues/12/spurious-migrations-on-python-3 which was fixed like this : https://bitbucket.org/psagers/django-otp/commits/7b0224ae83bcaaad290245b662d2dff9d2b3e6ec#Ldjango-otp/django_otp/plugins/otp_totp/migrations/0001_initial.pyF17T17 .

items.title: Current release is incompatible with Django >= 1.7; fixed in master
items.body:
django-otp only gained native Django migrations in version 0.3.0. The tag for 0.3.0 directly follows the commit that added native Django migrations to all apps.

https://bitbucket.org/psagers/django-otp/commits/01fe986b9fc23b136e92c798502c763e7e3a835d
https://bitbucket.org/psagers/django-otp/commits/cf6cd0b34451bfcd64956b008cca8d412e9d2c06

The current release of django-two-factor-auth is 1.2.1. It depends on django-otp>=0.2.0,<0.2.99. So `pip install django-two-factor-auth` installs `django-otp==0.2.7`. This makes it impossible to use Django >= 1.7 because the `'otp_static.StaticDevice'` model has a foreign key to the `AUTH_USER_MODEL` and no native Django migrations.

Indeed, Django doesn't allow models without migrations to depend on models with migrations, because the backwards compatibility layer starts by creating all models without migrations and then migrates those with migrations.

In practice we get the following error when trying to run our tests:

```
ALTER TABLE "otp_static_staticdevice" ADD CONSTRAINT "otp_static_staticdevi_user_id_107aea364f0973a5_fk_users_user_id" FOREIGN KEY ("user_id") REFERENCES "users_user" ("id") DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED

psycopg2.ProgrammingError: relation "users_user" does not exist
```

(We have `AUTH_USER_MODEL = "users.User"`.)

This was fixed in master six weeks ago. It would be very helpful if you could push a release to PyPI. (We manage our dependencies with pip-tools, which makes it inconvenient to pin git commits of libraries which have dependencies.)

items.title: Twilio gateway error
items.body:
When trying to send a sms via Twilio there is a gateway error due to the type of the device.number passed to the Twilio library. The type is of `<class 'two_factor.models.PhoneDevice'>` when it should be a string.

The file that needs editing is two_factor/gateways/twilio/gateway.py on line 60 `to=device.number,`. It should instead be something like `to=str(device.number),`. I think this bug is due to how phone number validation is done.
